direct_competitors.rationale: Head-to-head data (PARADIGM) showed OS benefit vs bevacizumab with chemo in left-sided RAS WT 1L; directly substitutes for cetuximab in the same biomarker-selected population.
Competes in 1L regimens (e.g., FOLFOX/FOLFIRI ± bevacizumab) especially in right-sided primaries or when clinicians prefer anti-angiogenic therapy over EGFR mAbs.
Alternative anti-angiogenic in later lines that can reduce use of EGFR antibodies in subsequent therapy sequences.
Later-line anti-angiogenic option; indirectly competes for treatment share in sequences that avoid EGFR antibodies.
Active in refractory MSS mCRC and can occupy later-line slots otherwise considered for EGFR rechallenge.

emerging_threats.phase: Phase 2 in mCRC; tumor-agnostic accelerated approval

emerging_threats.biomarker: MSS mCRC (signals stronger without active liver metastases)

key_biomarkers.clinical_utility: Mandatory for EGFR mAb eligibility; predicts benefit to cetuximab/panitumumab
Left-sided primaries derive greater benefit from EGFR mAbs; right-sided show limited benefit
Negative predictor for EGFR mAbs; guides use of BRAF-targeted combinations
Identifies candidates for HER2-targeted regimens that compete with EGFR mAbs, especially in later lines and potentially 1L
Higher expression correlates with greater EGFR mAb benefit in RAS WT disease

resistance_mechanisms.frequency: Common acquired mechanism (~20–30% of resistant clones)
resistance_mechanisms.treatment_options: Consider panitumumab sensitivity in S492R; clinical trials of next-gen EGFR agents/ADCs; switch to anti-angiogenic regimens

resistance_mechanisms.frequency: Common (~30–50% at progression on EGFR mAbs)
resistance_mechanisms.treatment_options: Avoid EGFR mAbs; consider anti-angiogenic or chemo options; monitor ctDNA for potential rechallenge after mutant clone decay
Switch to HER2-targeted therapy (tucatinib + trastuzumab; trastuzumab deruxtecan)
Consider clinical trials combining MET inhibition with EGFR blockade; alternative non-EGFR regimens
Targeted combinations in trials (e.g., BRAF/MEK ± EGFR) or switch to anti-angiogenic/chemo

sidedness_stratification.rationale: Prospective and retrospective data show superior outcomes with EGFR mAbs plus chemo in left-sided RAS WT primaries.
Right-sided tumors harbor adverse biology (e.g., BRAF mutation, MSI, distinct microenvironment) with limited benefit from EGFR mAbs in 1L.

paradigm_shifts.old: Bevacizumab-based chemotherapy used broadly regardless of sidedness
paradigm_shifts.new: EGFR mAb + chemo favored in left-sided RAS WT 1L
paradigm_shifts.impact: Shifts 1L market share toward cetuximab/panitumumab in left-sided disease

paradigm_shifts.new: Extended RAS testing (KRAS/NRAS exons 2/3/4) required before EGFR mAbs
paradigm_shifts.impact: Narrows eligible population to true RAS WT and optimizes benefit

paradigm_shifts.new: ctDNA-guided strategies (e.g., EGFR rechallenge after mutant clone decay)
paradigm_shifts.impact: Preserves EGFR mAb utility in later lines for selected RAS/BRAF WT by ctDNA

paradigm_shifts.old: No effective HER2-directed options in mCRC
paradigm_shifts.new: HER2-targeted regimens (tucatinib + trastuzumab; T-DXd) with growing use and movement toward 1L in HER2+ RAS WT
paradigm_shifts.impact: Diverts a biomarker-defined subset from EGFR antibodies

exclusions.rationale: Different competitive sets, not relevant to RAS WT setting
